title: 103_hr3332
content: The "Police Accountability Act of 1993" may be cited as the short title for this Act. It includes provisions for pattern or practice cases. The "Police Accountability Act of 1993" prohibits unlawful conduct by governmental authorities or law enforcement officers that deprives individuals of their constitutional rights. The Attorney General can take civil action to address violations, and injured persons can also seek civil remedies. The "Police Accountability Act of 1993" allows individuals to seek civil remedies for violations of their constitutional rights by law enforcement officers. In civil actions, prevailing plaintiffs may receive attorneys' fees and costs, and governmental bodies are liable for such fees. The term "law enforcement officer" refers to officials authorized to investigate, arrest, or detain individuals for criminal offenses. SEC. 3. CRIMINAL PENALTY. Amends Chapter 13 of title 18, United States Code by adding SEC. 248. POLICE BRUTALITY. SEC. 248 of Chapter 13 of title 18, United States Code addresses police brutality. It defines the offense as law enforcement officers using excessive force under the color of law. The punishment includes fines, imprisonment up to life if death occurs, and up to 10 years for bodily injury. The term 'law enforcement officer' refers to officials authorized to investigate, arrest, or detain individuals suspected or convicted of criminal offenses. The Attorney General is required to collect and publish data on complaints of excessive force by law enforcement officers. A report analyzing these complaints must be submitted to Congress, including details on the racial composition of complainants and officers accused of excessive force. Guidelines and procedures for data submission will be established. Data acquired under this section has limitations on its use. Data collected under this section must be used for research or statistical purposes only, with strict confidentiality to protect identities. The Attorney General will publish an annual summary of the data. States must provide information on complaints to the Attorney General to receive Criminal Justice Assistance Funds. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 addresses complaints of excessive force by law enforcement officers. Section 503(a)(12) applies to applications submitted one year after the enactment of the Act.
